Okay, those are a little different. The baremetal and bmc prefixes are joined with other things to generate the final name. For example: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-virtual-baremetal/blob/ff4d8fa4e27622ef2b08db10f8d7eafaa397166a/templates/bmc.yaml#L113

I guess it gets a bit fuzzy because we're processing parameters here and then Heat consumes them too, so I can see the argument for calling this a prefix (although in that case everything that gets an id should be a prefix).

In any case, it's probably not worth blocking this over.

doc/source/contributor/unit_tests.rst.message:
Python 3.5 isn't supported in Victoria.

I'm not sure what the best way to handle this is.  The way tox.ini is set up for the default enviroment (what you get if you just run 'tox -- -n <testname>' ) is running "python3" which is whatever version of python 3 is the default on the system running the tests.  You can say 'tox -e py310' and tox will try to find a Python 3.10 interpreter on the system (and if it can't will skip all the tests and give you a message:

  SKIPPED:  py310: InterpreterNotFound: python3.10

So you can run the unit tests for any version of python that's available on your system.  Which ones you should choose are determined by the OpenStack wide official supported python runtimes for that release:

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/

> The way tox.ini
 > is set up for the default enviroment (what you get if you just run
 > 'tox -- -n <testname>' ) is running "python3" which is whatever
 > version of python 3 is the default on the system running the tests.

Actually, that's not correct.  The tox.ini defines a 'envlist' of what environments are run by default if you just run 'tox' with no environment.  You can say 'tox -e py3' and then it will use whatever your system's default python is.

As noted below, it is just a clarification of required/optional parameters rather than refactoring.
"Clarifying optional parameters in create_volume" makes more sense to me.

To me, this change just clarifies what are required parameters and what are optional. Optional parameters for create_volume are passed as "keyword" arguments, while we can still pass them by positional arguments.

openstack_dashboard/api/cinder.py.message: I am okay with this change as the cinder API does not always require volume_type argument and if None is specified cinder determines it based on the situation (snapshot, volume or image).

openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/v.message:
I am struggling to understand what is the intention of this change? You changed api.cinder.volume_create so that 'volume_type' argument is now optional, but you still continue to pass 'volume_type' here. Why do you need to pass volume_type? 
Your change in api.cinder and this file look inconsistent.

From Cinder API perspective, an empty string and None value for volume type are the same.

We pass None as default to not specify it excplicitly
We need to pass volume type here because a user can provide a non-default value

Thus, I have the following questions:

- What does "None" (of the default value of api.cinder.volume_create()) mean?
- Do '' (empty string) and None have same meaning? If so, we should use one of them more consistently. Otherwise I cannot have a confident that we can maintain the code reliably.

The above are the main reasons I am confused with this patch and its purpose.

In addition, all optional parameters are passed <name>=<var> style. volume_type is now optional in the function definition, so volume_type=volume_type looks more consistent.

volume_type here cannot be dropped because data['type'] is populated even when 'snapshot_source' is specified in the create from. I confirmed this by adding a log message in handle() here. This happens because the type filed is just hidden in the form.

If you would like to refer data['type'] directly, it should be updated based on 'volume_source_type' for example in clean(). Otherwise, this does not work.

I am not sure which is better. Most parameters are adjusted here. Adjusting only "volume_type" parameter  in other place is clear or not.

The same comment applies to L.405 too.
It would be nice to move it to around L.365 as we get most values from the input data there.

I cannot understand why this change is related to api.cinder change. You mentioned in the commit message that None is the default value and cinder handles it gracefully but you specify an empty string now. It looks like different and inconsistent from what you mention in the commit message.
it's a value from user-filled form (mocked in line #493)

I know it, but if None means the default volume type, it is better to use None rather than '' (empty string). It looks more consistent to me. If it is just because the volume create form returns an empty string, we should use None and an empty string more consistently.

I think there is a misunderstanding. Clark meant if this line is necessary at all. Yes it is necessary since the what is already initialized is the set of changes dbs (per gerrit server). This line creates the changes db for the specific server if necessary.

If we want to make this nicer we could use a defaultdict for self.gerrit_changes_dbs and just do this here:

I wonder if we need an aggregation object just to bundle up all of these required resource objects. Then we can do something like:

  self.test_resource_objects = TestResourceObjects(self.config, self.changes, ..., self.git_url_with_auth, self.addCleanup)
  executor_connections = TestConnectionRegistry(self.test_resource_objects)
  self.scheds = SchedulerTestManager()
  self.scheds.create(self.test_resource_objects)

Then in test_web.py do similar for the ZuulWebFixture:

  ZuulWebFixture(self.test_resource_objects)

This is a bit hand wavy, it just seems we've got a bunch of common resources we need in places and that may simplify test setup methods.

Yes, the (Test)Connection registry bundles all the connections and their drivers. I would probably not bundle everything in one resource bundle object but maybe type/purpose specific bundles (e.g. this connection registry). But open to change that (maybe in a different change?)
Perhaps put the thread name here so that the thread names, ids, and tracebacks are all grouped together.
Done

In order to simplify the SchedulerTestManager and SchedulerTestApp does it make sense to pass in a premade TestConnectionRegistry to scheds.create() and drop self.changes from the init method entirely?

It reduces the number of arguments and SchedulerTestApp can set its self.foo values using the values from TestConnectionRegistry.

I am more for leaving it more flat than encapsulating it inside TestConnectionRegistry. We would need to make public attributes, e.g., "config", "changes" in TestConnectionRegistry only for that purpose in order to be able to use them in SchedulerTestManager and SchedulerTestApp. While it will make the number of parameters less it will imho decrease the navigability and readability of the code. Here its more clear what a SchedulerTestManager and SchedulerTestApp need. In case of adding/removing one or more parameters to one of these calls less changes will be needed.

One point may be to reuse TestConnectionRegistry in SchedulerTestApp. I am not sure if it is a good idea to share the same connection objects between "ExecutorServer" and "SchedulerTestApp"? It seams to me that currently we simulate the real setup better by having 2 separate instances. Or am I missing something?

Moving the "changes" parameter from SchedulerTestManager to the "create" method makes sense.
We should avoid the double underscores as mentioned in other changes. Particularly for testing being able to access or override methods is useful.
Done: You can always increase visibility if there is need to. Minimal necessary visibility was the approach here.
See above.
Done
It would probably be a good idea to clean these up too in a separate change.
I think we don't have to differentiate per driver here. We access each db here by server name anyway which is unique enough.
Done

roles/merge-output-to-logs/tasks/main.ya.message:
In the case where work_root and log_root share a fs doing a mv should be significantly faster. Instead of doing a proper copy then an rm can we express a file move in ansible somehow?

I think the answer may be no, but wanted to call that out here so that if it is no we record that and if it is yes we can fix it.

Indeed, that is the exact reason why there is no move module, lack of idempotency. I do not like it and apparently nobody bothered to propose such a module yet.

IMHO, there is a way to describe a move in an idempotent way: "assure there are not files remaining on source". What one should test is not if files were effectively moved, only that the source files no longer exist. If you think about, we can say that deleting files is not idempotent too, as you cannot delete them twice, still you can assure that they are absent at the end.
There isn't a "mv" module as such.  I can't find any direct reference but I would guess it has to do with some intersection of idempotent behaviour, atomicity and operations

doc/examples/Dockerfile.opensuse_15.message: in a k8s env, there is no value in this.
yes, but even then, the port exposed is a config param both in the application and on the cli - in practice, this metadata typically causes more confusion that intsolves.
In dev environment containers could be run w/o k8s, right?
All right. Convinced me. Thank you.
should this not be an arg (with a default)
Made it parametrized with default value 1000.
in that case we should use a uid other than 1000, as without uid namespaces this will result in collisions with users on the host that may be undesired.
Why? We only (mostly) care that app is run under unprivileged user by default. If needed, user could be overridden on container launch.
but we are not using those params, also this logic looks to be written from the perspective of people consuming application images, rather than base distro images.

Docker Inc.'s recommendation:

  > You should avoid RUN apt-get upgrade or dist-upgrade, as
  > many of the “essential” packages from the parent images
  > can’t upgrade inside an unprivileged container. If a
  > package contained in the parent image is out-of-date, you
  > should contact its maintainers. If you know there’s a
  > particular package, foo, that needs to be updated, use
  > apt-get install -y foo to update automatically.

https://docs.docker.com/v17.12/develop/develop-images/dockerfile_best-practices/#apt-get

I think we misunderstand each other.

When we use versioned base image, we are more or less sure that versions of software in upstream image in our image match. When we try to update OS from inside of the container, then those versions would possibly not be matching.

Then all packages update could fail, because container is restricted (no separate kernel, some virtual file systems are missing, etc.).

In addition to that we want to reuse upstream tested image as much as possible, and we want to better reuse image layers cache, which update would invalidate.

when stringing commands together like this, it is best to prefix the command block with `set -ex` of similar to both allow commands run to be displayed in approximate order with their output, and also catch failures that `&&` will miss.
Totally agree. Thank you. And also pipefail would be useful in some cases (curl ... | tar ...).

doc/source/code-conventions.rst.message: Is there an easier way to do this aside from copy-pasting into a new file to run shellcheck on?

Yes, it's supposed to be Zuul job.
Here is an example (WIP) https://review.opendev.org/#/c/674409/10/tools/gate/scripts/030-lint-divingbell-scripts.sh

> Is there an easier way to do this aside from copy-pasting into a
 > new file to run shellcheck on?

I am curious how a gate will enforce this as well.

Linting things in helm chart seems like a noble goal, but they can very well be templates that even if you copy&paste out, they are not well form go/python/bash and conventional linting will fail. You will need to template everything out and find the right things to lint from the yaml.

It may be a lot of manual efforts for very little value-add. However, if this can be incorporated into a zuul job, I would like that too for the OSH/OSH-I/OSH-A repositories.

doc/source/develop/code-conventions.rst.message: As Tin said, this is a noble goal, but how will we accomplish this? It's not possible to lint raw gotpl, and rendering the template will cause strange formatting anyway (see Divingbell). By the time the template is rendered, nobody will see the shell code.

We have a couple of 'server add X' commands plus a couple of 'server X create' commands:

  server add fixed ip
  server add floating ip
  server add network
  server add port
  server add security group
  server add volume

  server backup create
  server dump create
  server group create
  server image create

The former seem to attach existing, non-server resources to an existing server. The latter seem to creating new non-server resources and would maybe make more sense with hyphens:

  server-backup create
  server-dump create
  server-group create
  server-image create

I don't think either 'server add tag' or 'server tag create' really makes sense. Tags are not a resource. Rather, they're an attribute of the server. What do you think about using the 'server set' command, e.g. 'server set [--tag TAG [--tag TAG ...]]'? You could remove tags with 'server unset --tag TAG'

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
So the first boot selects the 4k pages over the 1G page. It can as the user did not specified the page size, so nova can choose. I guess if the user did not specify the page size then the second boot is free to select the 1 piece of 1G page as well.

I feel that I'm missing something. 

What is the defined meaning of not having a page size specified:
* nova free to chose whatever page size available
* nova defaults to 4k pages if pagesize is not defined by the user

Does the fact that we have pinned CPUs in the instance changes the above definition?
thanks. Based on this it is a fault to allow the second boot to use the 1G pages.

> So the first boot selects the 4k pages over the 1G page.

Yup.

 > It can as
 > the user did not specified the page size, so nova can choose.

Sort of. It's not free to choose any page size. Rather, it will choose the smallest possible pagesize on that host. For x86 hosts, this is *always* 4k.

 > I
 > guess if the user did not specify the page size then the second
 > boot is free to select the 1 piece of 1G page as well.

Nope. As above, it will always try to use the smallest possible page size on that host. On x86 at least, you must always have some amount of 4k pages. The kernel won't boot otherwise.

 > I feel that I'm missing something.
 > 
 > What is the defined meaning of not having a page size specified:
 > * nova free to chose whatever page size available
 > * nova defaults to 4k pages if pagesize is not defined by the user

The latter. Nova defaults to the smallest pagesize on that host, which for x86 is 4k

 > Does the fact that we have pinned CPUs in the instance changes the
 > above definition?

Having pinned CPUs mean you can't overcommit. The instance will still use the smallest pagesize (4k on x86) but you can no longer overcommit on that inventory.

if a user does not specify a page size nova must use 4k small pages it may not use hugepages of any size.

stephen the reason you need to set hw:mem_page_size when doing pinning has nothing to do with hugepages.

it has to do with how we track memory. and how instance with shared cpus work.

to safely be able to mix vms with pCPUs and vCPUS on the same host all insntance must have hw:mem_page_size set. if they dont then the pinned instance which have there memory pinned to the same numa node as there cpus can be killed as a result of a oom event on the host.

seting hw:mem_page_size to small or large causes use to pin the memory of the guest and track that in the resouce tracker. if we dont do that then we wont correctly track the memory usage of the shared instnaces and or the pinned instances properly.

so if you are mixing floating and pinned vms on the same host it is absolutely required.

also this branch will only ever look at the non hugepage memroy. so if 50% of the memory is allcoated to hugepages it will make no differnece the pagezise we will be checking here will be just the 4k memory.

> stephen the reason you need to set hw:mem_page_size when doing
 > pinning has nothing to do with hugepages.
 > 
 > it has to do with how we track memory. and how instance with shared
 > cpus work.
 > 
 > to safely be able to mix vms with pCPUs and vCPUS on the same host
 > all insntance must have hw:mem_page_size set. if they dont then the
 > pinned instance which have there memory pinned to the same numa
 > node as there cpus can be killed as a result of a oom event on the
 > host.

Unless you're using hugepages though, all pages can be swapped to disk so I'm not sure why having memory restricted to a single NUMA node would make 'hw:mem_page_size' compulsory. It might make it *more likely* that you'll have OOM events, but that's only because the instances that are stuck to one NUMA node doesn't have a chance to fall over to  memory from another. Theoretically you're dicing with OOM every time you run with overcommit.

 > seting hw:mem_page_size to small or large causes use to pin the
 > memory of the guest and track that in the resouce tracker. if we
 > dont do that then we wont correctly track the memory usage of the
 > shared instnaces and or the pinned instances properly.

Again, I don't know why this would be a critical issue if we didn't have hugepage-based instances since we always do a non-pagesize aware memory check for every instance (via placement). You're correct that our memory-page tracking wouldn't be able to track the usage by non-pagesize-aware instances, but again, those instances could always just run on another core.

 > so if you are mixing floating and pinned vms on the same host it is
 > absolutely required.
 > 
 > also this branch will only ever look at the non hugepage memroy. so
 > if 50% of the memory is allcoated to hugepages it will make no
 > differnece the pagezise we will be checking here will be just the
 > 4k memory.

Yes, but later in this code, we have a check to prevent overcommit - it's [1] - and that *does* include hugepage memory, so that 50% will be included. If we had already allocated the non-hugepage memory, that check would pass because hey, 50% of the memory is "unused". That's the whole point of this change :)

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/631053/5/nova/virt/hardware.py@a1016

> use of hw:mem_page_size disabel overcommit
 > using cpu pinning does not.

That's not true.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/20.1.0/nova/virt/hardware.py#L1016-L1024

 > having staid that if you use cpu pinnign you should always
 > set hw:mem_page_size to something small, large it does not matter
 > but it should be set to a value or else we wotn do numa aware
 > memory checking.

That's useful but not necessary unless you also have instances using hugepages on the host. Mixing pagesize-aware instances and non-pagesize-aware instances does cause issues.

 > so cpu pinning alone is not a correct way to prevent over commit
 > but it is not the most evil apporch either.

As above, it is correct.

 > strictly sepaking this is a backward incomaptable change in
 > behavior and the admin has not request over commit to be disabled
 > but it mig be the lesser of two evils.

This is not really true. Previously, if a host had e.g. 50% of its memory allocated to hugepages, an admin might be able to boot one or more pinned but non-pagesize aware instances that, combined, consumed more than 50% of the host memory. However, not all of this memory was actually allocated so this was broken behavior. It's only backwards incompatible in so far as instances now get what they're actually asking for.

 > numa in placment shoudl fix this properly next cycle.

We've been saying that for a few years now :)

neutron/tests/fullstack/resources/client.message:
according to the fact that in fullstack tests each test in fact has got own neutron-server and own db, there is no way that some other test will create resources which overlays with resources created in "our" test.
So I suspect that the issue described in the related bug is more due to fact that create_subnet POST request was processed for long time and it was retried already (something what we have seen pretty often in e.g. some tempest jobs).
And if my undestanding is true, we will end up here with 2 subnets created in the same network, which may lead to some other unpredictable failures in the future.
So maybe, instead of retrying here creation of subnet, we should in the except block try to get subnet for specific network, compare it's cidr (and maybe other attributes which were given) and simply return that subnet if it exists.
I think this name is still good, but if you have a better name, please suggest

src/templates/rocky/octavia.conf.message:
actually according to [1] you can use the 2 new config options here instead, and then you don't need the new file for stein. It will accomplish the same. In fact, they actually override status_update_threads, so I'd say it would be preferred to use them, since we are adding them now.

Also, raising one concern here that I think is worth debating about. Through the workers config option one would expect that if the options.workers value is 8, then octavia will use 8 threads. According to the code, and as I understand it, that will not be true, as in [2] it creates 2  ProcessPoolExecutors. Therefore it will use 16 threads, leaving less threads for other units/apps. Perhaps the config should be set to "options.workers/2" ?


[1] https://github.com/openstack/octavia/blob/126ad303ac998f2fa36de572bb37cb36f366913a/octavia/common/config.py#L678

[2] https://github.com/openstack/octavia/blob/418ea0908c44c97261d353a531ef533613739618/octavia/amphorae/drivers/health/heartbeat_udp.py#L57

Not sure I'm following 100%. Do you mean that Octavia should only use 8 threads in total even when it has multiple types of services?

For example with nova-c-c charm, it has a bunch of services and it will spawn 8 threads (in this case) *per service*. Does nova-c-c have to set options.workers/6 or options.workers/8 (potentially a singe thread per service in the end)? I don't think it's an expected behavior either from an operator point of view.

> actually according to [1] you can use the 2 new config options here instead, and then you don't need the new file for stein. It will accomplish the same. In fact, they actually override status_update_threads, so I'd say it would be preferred to use them, since we are adding them now.

Hmm that is a good point, I wasn't aware that it was the same unfortunate behavior for all other services as well. I say unfortunate because, as an operator, if I have 32 threads, and I want to make sure every service has a dedicated thread, and I'm planning to dedicate 8 to nova, it is much easier to just say "juju config nova-cloud-controller workers-multiplier=0.25" and boom I have 8 threads dedicated to nova and 24 threads available for my other stuff, but that is not the case... I would need to be aware of how nova uses those threads, therefore looking at nova.conf I see it is being used 3 times. So I would need to run "juju config nova-cloud-controller workers-multiplier=0.09" to end with 9 total threads for nova, where it will use 3 for each service, and then have 23 threads left for my other stuff.

Anyway, let's just be consistent here and move forward as is.
